configuration.note: All activation evaluations use Neuronpedia API. Activation threshold is dynamically calculated from top 10 high-activating API exemplars (average of max activations / 2). Generation Evaluation uses top 10 high-activating exemplars. Prediction Evaluation uses selected exemplars directly from API (excluding top 10), with activation values already available (no API calls needed for activations). model_name and sae_path are kept for record-keeping only and are not used for any calculations.

explanation.description: Feature 97664 activates on pulmonary-domain lexemes in running text, especially the space-prefixed token “ lung” (lowercase, mid-sentence) and the subword “monary” in “pulmonary.” Activations are moderate (≈1.31–2.73 for “ lung”; ≈2.28 for “monary”), while structurally marked forms are suppressed: hyphenated oncology modifiers (“small-/non-small-cell lung cancer”) are low (≈0.00–0.29), plural “lungs” is 0.00, line-initial/title-case “Lung …” (BPE “ung”) is ≈0.04, and string-initial lowercase “lung …” is ≈0.01. Generic “-ung” substrings (e.g., “Hungary,” “Young,” “plunge”) show 0.00, indicating specificity to pulmonary lexemes rather than the character sequence “ung.”
explanation.evidence:
- Test 18: 'We examine lung anatomy.' → 2.7344 at ' lung' (supports H4: mid-sentence “ lung” activation)
- Test 13: 'He has lung cancer.' → 2.5312 at ' lung' (supports H4: unhyphenated “ lung” activation)
- Test 17: 'Pulmonary disease is common.' → 2.2812 at 'monary' (supports H4: activation on “pulmonary”)
- Test 21: 'Pulmonary embolism is fatal.' → 2.2812 at 'monary' (supports H4: replication on “pulmonary”)
- Test 8: 'The lung is vital.' → 1.6016 at ' lung' (supports H4)
- Test 9: 'He studied lung physiology.' → 1.6797 at ' lung' (supports H4)
- Test 11: 'He developed lung cancer.' → 1.3125 at ' lung' (supports H4)
- Test 4: 'The patient had non-small-cell lung cancer.' → 0.1406 at ' lung' (supports H4: hyphenation suppression)
- Test 6: 'She was diagnosed with small-cell lung cancer.' → 0.2891 at ' lung' (supports H4: hyphenation suppression)
- Test 20: 'small cell lung cancer.' → 0.0532 at ' lung' (supports H4: modifier suppression)
- Test 14: 'They treat non small cell lung cancer.' → 0.0000 (supports H4: modifier suppression)
- Test 16: 'The lungs are vital.' → 0.0000 (supports H4: plural suppression)
- Test 22: 'His lungs collapsed.' → 0.0000 (supports H4: plural suppression)
- Test 15: 'lung function tests.' → 0.0063 at 'lung' (refutes H1: string-initial lowercase “lung” weak)
- Tests 1/2/7/10/12: line-initial/title-case “Lung …” → 0.0396 at 'ung' (refutes H1/H2: no boost at “Lung” start)
- Test 3: 'Hungary is in Europe.' → 0.0000 (supports H3: generic “-ung” ignored)
- Test 5: 'Young people learn quickly.' → 0.0000 (supports H3: generic “-ung” ignored)
- Test 19: 'They plunge into water.' → 0.0000 (supports H3: generic “-ung” ignored)

labels.text: Pulmonary lexemes in running text: space-prefixed “ lung” (lowercase, mid-sentence) OR “pulmonary” (“-monary” subword), with suppression for hyphenated modifiers, plural “lungs,” and title-/string-initial forms; ignores generic “-ung” substrings.

explanation.label1: Pulmonary lexemes in running text: space-prefixed “ lung” (lowercase, mid-sentence) OR “pulmonary” (“-monary” subword), with suppression for hyphenated modifiers, plural “lungs,” and title-/string-initial forms; ignores generic “-ung” substrings.

generated_examples: The patient showed pulmonary edema on the chest radiograph.
We monitored pulmonary function after the marathon training session.
During auscultation, the doctor heard crackles over the lung bases.
She aspirated a peanut into the lung, causing sudden wheeze.
They biopsied a lung nodule during a routine bronchoscopy.
Computed tomography revealed pulmonary emboli in the right lower lobe.
Inflammation scarred the lung parenchyma after repeated infections.
He studies lung cancer epidemiology using national registries.
The anesthetist protected the lung with careful ventilation settings.
Clinicians suspect pulmonary hypertension based on exertional dyspnea and edema.

explanation.description: mentions of the lungs or pulmonary system, particularly in medical/oncology contexts.
mentions of the lungs or pulmonary system, particularly in medical/oncology contexts.

generated_examples: CT revealed a spiculated lung mass consistent with primary carcinoma.
Pulmonary nodules enlarged after chemotherapy, suggesting progressive metastatic disease.
Bronchoscopy confirmed adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe.
PET-CT showed hypermetabolic lesions throughout both lungs and mediastinum.
The pulmonologist scheduled a lobectomy for stage I lung cancer.
Pleural effusion caused dyspnea in a patient with metastatic lung carcinoma.
Molecular testing of the lung tumor revealed an EGFR exon 19 deletion.
Radiation oncology planned stereotactic ablation of a peripheral pulmonary lesion.
Smoking history and chronic cough prompted screening for pulmonary malignancy.
Severe hemoptysis originated from a cavitary lung metastasis.

prediction_evaluation.note: Prediction Evaluation uses selected exemplars directly from API (excluding top 10 used for Generation Evaluation). Exemplars are categorized into high, medium, and low activation groups from remaining exemplars, and randomly selected from each group. Activation values are already available from exemplars, so no API calls are needed to get activations. This avoids bias from explanation text and ensures diverse activation levels in evaluation examples.
